journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Optimal impact angle control guidance law considering the seeker’s field-of-view limits

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST), Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Bong-Gyun Park, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST), 373-1 Guseong-dong Yuseong-gu, Daejon 305-701, Republic of Korea. Email: bgpark@fdcl.kaist.ac.kr

abstract.p: A new optimal guidance problem with impact angle constraint and seeker’s field-of-view limits is investigated for a missile with a strapdown seeker. Impact angle control to satisfy the terminal flight path angle constraint causes missile trajectories to be very curved. Since a strapdown seeker has a narrower field-of-view than a gimbaled seeker, a missile with a strapdown seeker using the impact angle control guidance law can miss its target within the field-of-view during the homing phase, leading to the failure of the mission. Therefore, considering the seeker’s field-of-view limits is a key issue for missiles with strapdown seekers when implementing the impact angle control guidance law. To handle the seeker’s field-of-view limits in the homing guidance problem, a look angle, which is defined as the angle between the velocity vector and the line-of-sight, is considered as an inequality constraint. Based on the optimal control theory with a state variable inequality constraint, the optimal impact angle control guidance law with the seeker’s field-of-view limits is designed. The proposed guidance law is made up of three types of optimal acceleration commands: the first command is to reach the maximum look angle of the seeker, the second is to keep the seeker look angle constant on the constraint boundary, and the third is to intercept the target with the desired impact angle. Nonlinear simulations are performed to validate the proposed approach. In addition, comparisons with other guidance laws considering the limitation of the seeker look angle are carried out via nonlinear simulations, and the results show that the proposed guidance law is more efficient in terms of the control energy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A homing missile acquires target information from a seeker to implement the guidance law. The typical type of seeker is an inertially stabilized gimbaled seeker. It is isolated from the missile body motion through gimbals, rate sensors, and servo motors. The gimbaled seeker has the advantages of a wide field-of-view (FOV) and direct measurement of the inertial line-of-sight (LOS) rate but has the disadvantages of high cost, mechanical complexity, and large size and weight. Another type of seeker is the strapdown seeker, which is rigidly attached to the missile body. The strapdown seeker can reduce the mechanical complexity of implementation and calibration, size, and weight. There are also significant cost savings by eliminating gimbals. For these advantages, significant studies on the strapdown seeker have been conducted during the last several years.1–3 However, the strapdown seeker has a narrower FOV than the gimballed seeker, so a homing missile with a strapdown seeker is limited to engagement geometries.

Recently, impact angle control has been generally required for homing missiles. For example, anti-tank missiles require a top-attack mode to attack the upper part of a tank, which is relatively weaker than the front or sides, as well as precision interception. In addition, anti-ship missiles rapidly climb and attack the deck near the target ship after sea-skimming to avoid radar and infrared detection during their approach, and ballistic missiles can reduce the miss distance produced by navigation errors impacting the target vertically.

Previous works on the problem of impact angle control can be mainly classified into two categories: optimal guidance laws and modified proportional navigation (PN) type laws. Kim and Grider4 proposed a suboptimal guidance law for the reentry vehicles with impact attitude angle, which is probably the first published work on designing an impact angle control guidance law. The optimal solution for the simple rendezvous problem which minimizes the performance index including the terminal lateral position and velocity was solved by Bryson and Ho.5 The solution can be utilized for impact angle control if the rendezvous course is set to the predetermined collision course. Song and Cho6 studied an optimal impact angle control law for missiles with varying velocity against moving targets, and a target tracking filter is combined with the proposed guidance law for actual applications. Ryoo et al.7 proposed a generalized formulation of energy minimization optimal guidance laws for missiles with arbitrary order dynamics to intercept the target with the desired impact angles. As an extension of this study, they also proposed the optimal guidance law with terminal constraints of miss distance and impact angle solving a linear quadratic optimal control problem with the energy cost weighted by a power of the time-to-go.8 To intercept ground targets, Oza and Padhi9 presented an impact-angle-constrained nonlinear suboptimal guidance law for air-to-ground missiles, and this law was designed using recently developed model predictive static programming (MPSP).10

Other approaches to control the impact angle are mainly concerned with modified PN-type laws. Kim et al.11 introduced a biased proportional navigation guidance (PNG) law to impact targets with angular constraints. This guidance law is a variation of the conventional PNG law, which is combined with a supplementary time-varying bias to control the impact angle. Using the principle of following a circular arc to the target, Manchester and Savkin12 proposed a circular-navigation-guidance (CNG) law to achieve the desired impact angle. Erer and Merttopçuoğlu13 proposed the two-phase guidance scheme between biased pure proportional navigation (PPN) and PN adjusting the integral of bias to satisfy the terminal impact angle. A composite guidance law for impact angle control against stationary targets and nonstationary nonmaneuvering targets, which was based on conventional PNG and PNG with a varying navigation constant, was studied by Ratnoo and Ghose.14,15 However, most of the studies mentioned above did not take the seeker’s FOV limits into account in designing the impact angle control guidance law.

During the homing phase, maintaining the seeker lock-on condition, which the target is located in the inside the FOV, is very important to successfully achieve the target interception. Conventional PNG generates the missile trajectory decreasing the seeker’s look angle for a stationary target, so the lock-on failure is not critical for the homing guidance.16 However, since impact angle control significantly changes the flight trajectory of the missile compared with the guidance laws only to achieve zero miss distance such as PNG, a missile can miss its target within the FOV during the homing phase if the seeker’s FOV is narrow. Especially, it is a critical problem for a missile with a strapdwon seeker having a narrow FOV in order to implement the impact angle control guidance law. This is one of the critical reasons for the strapdown seeker not being utilized much for the homing missile to apply various guidance laws so far, although the strapdown seeker has many advantages as previously mentioned.

In this article, we propose the energy optimal impact angle control guidance law with the seeker’s FOV limits for a constant speed missile with a strapdown seeker using optimal control theory. To handle the seeker’s FOV limits in the guidance problem, the look angle dynamics, which is derived by the geometrical relationship between the flight path angle and the LOS angle, is used. The seeker look angle must be handled as the state variable inequality constraint to prevent a lock-on failure during the homing phase. Therefore, conditions to consider the look angle inequality constraint are added to the optimal control problem which only includes conditions to achieve the specified impact angle and zero miss distance. The main feature of the proposed law is that it accurately satisfies constraints on the desired impact angle as well as zero miss distance maintaining the lock-on condition during the homing phase even though the seeker has the narrow FOV. Moreover, the proposed law also minimizes the control energy, which can minimize aerodynamic drag.

To our knowledge, many studies on impact angle control guidance laws handling the seeker’s FOV limits have been not conducted as compared with that importance. Manchester and Savkin12 used a hybrid guidance law composed of CNG and modified deviated pure pursuit guidance following an arc of a logarithmic spiral centered on the target in order to deal with the look angle saturation. This article, however, did not directly consider the seeker’s FOV limits to design CNG. Xin et al.17 designed a guidance law that minimizes the velocity component perpendicular to the LOS to reduce the seeker look angle. They formulated the guidance problem as a nonlinear optimal control problem and then employed the θ−D technique,18 which has been developed recently as the nonlinear control method to solve regulator problems, to design the guidance law. This law is a suboptimal one and needs to adjust the optimal weighting matrices in the integrand of the quadratic performance index as engagement scenarios. Sang and Tahk19 proposed a guidance law switching logic between the original guidance law and the constant look angle guidance law using Lyapunov theory. Any guidance law can be used as the original guidance law, and the derived constant target look angle guidance law is used when the seeker look angle approaches the FOV limit. This logic is simple and easy to apply, but it is not an optimal one to minimize the control energy during the homing phase. Compared with the above mentioned works, the guidance law proposed in this article has been designed considering the seeker’s FOV limits and impact angle constraint simultaneously and need not adjust the weighting matrices to treat the seeker’s FOV limits and to satisfy the desired impact angle constraint as well as zero miss distance. Also, the proposed law can generate the optimal missile trajectory during homing phase, so the control energy is spent less than other methods.

The proposed guidance law is based on optimal control theory considering a state variable inequality constraint. In the 1960s, many studies on optimal control problems with a state variable inequality constraint were conducted.5,20–22 To deal with the state variable inequality constraint, certain conditions must be added to the Euler–Lagrange equations during intervals in which the solution path lies on the constraint boundary. If the control variable is not explicitly involved in an inequality constraint function, we take successive time derivatives of this function until an expression which is explicitly dependent on the control variable is obtained and then impose additional constraints at the constraint boundary. The unconstrained arcs must satisfy tangency constraints at the entry and exit points between the unconstrained and constrained arcs. Hence, three kinds of optimal solutions are obtained from these results. The first solution is an unconstrained arc beginning at specified initial conditions and ending at the entry point onto the constraint boundary. The second solution is a constrained arc lying on the constraint boundary. The third solution is an unconstrained arc beginning at the exit point of the constraint boundary and ending at specified terminal conditions.

The optimal impact angle control guidance law in this article is designed as guidance phases using the optimal control theory with the state variable inequality constraint: the first guidance law for an initial guidance phase is to reach the maximum look angle of the seeker; the second guidance law for a mid-guidance phase is to maintain the maximum look angle; the third guidance law for a final guidance phase is to intercept the target with the desired impact angle. During the homing phase, the switching of the guidance phase occurs as the missile-target relative distance, which is uniquely determined using the relationship of the acceleration command and the constant of integration of the flight path angle between the end points of the constrained flight phase.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. In the following section, the impact angle control problem with the seeker’s FOV limits is formulated. Next, the optimal control problem with a state variable inequality constraint, which has already been reported in Speyer and Bryson,21 is briefly reviewed. The energy optimal guidance laws with a seeker look angle inequality constraint and an impact angle constraint are then derived in the later section. Nonlinear simulations, which were conducted to investigate the characteristics of the proposed guidance laws, are described in the next section. Finally, concluding remarks are given in the last section.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p:
Consider the two-dimensional homing guidance geometry of a missile with a strapdown seeker against a stationary target shown in Figure 1. Here, V is the missile velocity, and a is the acceleration applied normal to the velocity vector. The missile-target relative distance is denoted as r, and γ, γf and λ are the flight path angle, the desired impact angle, and the line-of-sight (LOS) angle, respectively. Figure 1.
Homing guidance geometry.

To directly handle the field-of-view (FOV) limitation of the strapdown seeker rigidly attached to the missile body, the angle-of-attack (AOA) dynamics is included in the system equation because the missile attitude angle (θ) is expressed in terms of the AOA (α) and the flight path angle (γ) as (1)θ=α+γ If the AOA dynamics is considered in designing the guidance law, then the missile is handled as a lag system, and the derived law is expressed in the complicated form.23 This kind of guidance law is also required to know the time constant of the system lag which is difficult to measure directly. Therefore, we will not consider the AOA dynamics in the guidance problem of this article in order to obtain a compact form of the guidance law for practical applications.
Under the assumption that the angle of attack of the missile is small and neglected, the seeker look angle σ between the velocity vector and the LOS can be defined to handle the FOV limits.19

The nonlinear equations of motion in this homing problem are given by (2)drdt=-Vcosσ
(3)dσdt=dγdt-dλdt=aV+Vsinσr
(4)dγdt=aV where t denotes time as the independent variable. The boundary conditions are given as follows (5)r (t0 )=r0,σ (t0 )=σ0,γ (t0 )=γ0
(6)r (tf )=rf,σ (tf )=σf,γ (tf )=γf The following look angle inequality constraint to consider the seeker’ FOV limits is also added (7)σ (t )≤σmax

The independent variable, t, can be changed to r because, from equation (2), r strictly decreases in time if |σ(t)| is less than π/2 for t∈[t0, tf].24 Therefore, under the assumption that V is constant and σ is small, the linearized state differential equations can be written as (8) [dσdrdγdr ]= [-1r000 ] [σγ ]+ [-1V2-1V2 ]a

The boundary conditions and the seeker look angle inequality constraint are now expressed as (9)σ (r0 )=σ0,γ (r0 )=γ0
(10)σ (rf )=σf,γ (rf )=γf
(11)σ (r )≤σmax

It is assumed that the missile has a lag-free system without guidance command limits and all information required for the guidance law can be perfectly obtained. It is also assumed that the stationary target is located within the seeker’s FOV limits of the missile at the beginning of the homing guidance phase, which is called lock-on before launch (LOBL).25

sec.title: Optimal control problem with a state variable inequality constraint
sec.p: Optimal control problems with a state variable inequality constraint have been described in many papers. Thus, these problems will only be reviewed briefly in this section.21

A general optimal control problem is finding u(t) on the time interval t∈[t0, tf] to minimize the Bolza performance index (12)J=ϕ [x (tf ),tf ]+∫t0 tfL [x (t ),u (t ),t ]dt subject to the state differential equations (13)x·=f [x (t ),u (t ),t ],x (t0 )=x0 the terminal conditions (14)ψ [x (tf ),tf ]=0 and the state variable inequality constraint (15)s [x (t ),t ]≤0 Here, the dot operator represents time derivatives; x(t) is an n × 1 vector of state variables; u(t) is a scalar control variable; ϕ and L are scalars; f is an n × 1 vector of known functions of x(t), u(t), and t, and is assumed everywhere differentiable with respect to x(t) and u(t); ψ is a q × 1 vector of known functions of x(tf) and tf, where q ≤ n; and s is a scalar function of x(t) and t. If p times derivatives of s[x(t), t] are required that u appears explicitly in the results, then this will be called a pth-order state variable inequality constraint. The subscripts 0 and f represent the initial and final states, respectively.

As shown in Figure 2, we assume a constrained arc for t1 ≤ t ≤ t2 and unconstrained arcs for t0 ≤ t ≤ t1 and t2 ≤ t ≤ tf. Now let us define y[x(t), t] as the p × 1 vector (16)y [x (t ),t ]=Δ {s [x (t ),t ]s (1 ) [x (t ),t ]:s (p-1 ) [x (t ),t ] } where s(i) = d(i)s/dt(i), and this function is zero on a constraint boundary. Thus, the dimension of the state space is reduced to n–p, and then z[x(t), t] as the (n–p) × 1 vector can be defined as (17)z [x (t ),t ]Δ= {z1 [x (t ),t ]:zn-p [x (t ),t ] } From equations (16) and (17), for the constrained arc, the state variables (x) can be expressed as (18)x= [y…z ] The pth time derivative of s[x(t), t] is also zero on the constraint boundary (19)s (p ) [x (t ),u (t ),t ]=0
Figure 2.
Typical state histories with an inequality constraint.

sec.title: Necessary conditions on unconstrained arcs
sec.p:
On the unconstrained arcs, solutions must satisfy equation (13) and (20)λ·T=-∂H∂x
(21)0=∂H∂u where λ is an n × 1 vector of the co-state variables, and H is the Hamiltonian defined as H = L + λTf. At the terminal time (tf), the solution must satisfy the terminal conditions, equation (14), and (22)λT (tf )= ∂G∂x |t=tf where G is the endpoint function defined as G = ϕ + νTΨ, and ν is a q × 1 vector of constants. At the initial time (t0), the solution must also satisfy the initial conditions in equation (13).

sec.title: Necessary conditions on a constrained arc
sec.p: On a constrained arc, the following equality constraint must be satisfied (23)y [x (t ),t ]=0 where y was defined in equation (16). The n–p vector (z) was also defined in equation (17), and then its differential equations can be expressed as (24)z·=g [z (t ),t ] In addition, the co-state differential equations are defined as (25)μ·T=-∂F∂z where μ is an (n–p) × 1 vector of the reduced co-state variables, and F is the Hamiltonian defined as F = L + μTg.

sec.title: Necessary conditions at a juncture between a constrained and an unconstrained arc
sec.p:
At entry and exit points, the unconstrained arcs must satisfy the following tangency constraints (26)y [x (tk ),tk ]=0,k=1,2 Also, the following conditions must be satisfied (27)μT=λTN att=t1andt=t2
(28)F=H+λT (M∂y∂t+N∂z∂t ) att=t1andt=t2 where (29) [M:N ]= [∂y∂x…∂z∂x ]-1

sec.title: Proof
sec.p: See Speyer and Bryson.21

From equations (18) and (27), the co-state variables associated with the reduced state variables (z) are continuous across the juncture points. The state variables (x) are also continuous across the juncture points if jump discontinuities in the state variables such as the optimal control problem of multistage launch vehicles are not considered. As a result, the two unconstrained arcs cannot be solved separately due to the coupling effect through z and μ. However, if the contribution of the constrained arc to the performance index is a function of its end points (independent variable or one component of x), then the two unconstrained arcs can be solved separately.22

sec.title: Optimal guidance law
sec.p:
In this section, we derive the optimal impact angle control laws for two cases. In the first case, the seeker does not have the FOV limits; in the other case, the seeker has the FOV limits. First, we solve an optimal control problem in which the control energy (30)J=12∫r0 rfa2dr is minimized subject to equations (8) to (10). Second, we solve the same problem, but the only difference is that the seeker look angle inequality constraint, equation (11), is added to the preceding problem. As shown in the previous section and in Figure 3, three types of optimal solutions will be obtained as the missile-target relative distance (r) when the seeker look angle inequality constraint is considered. The first optimal solution is to reach the maximum look angle during the initial guidance phase (r1 ≤ r ≤ r0), the second is to maintain the maximum look angle during the mid-guidance phase (r2 ≤ r ≤ r1), and the final is to intercept the target with the desired impact angle during the final guidance phase (rf ≤ r ≤ r2). Figure 3.
Typical look angle histories with seeker’s field-of-view limits.

sec.title: Optimal impact angle control guidance law without the seeker’s FOV limits
sec.p:
The Hamiltonian H is given by (31)H=12a2-λσ (aV2+σr )-λγaV2 where λσ and λγ are the co-state variables. Using equation (20), the co-state differential equations with respect to r are derived as (32)dλσdr=λσ1r
(33)dλγdr=0 where the terminal conditions are λσf=vσ and λγf=vγ. Hence, the solutions of equations (32) and (33) are obtained as (34)λσ=vσrfr
(35)λγ=vγ where νσ and νγ are constants to be determined to satisfy the terminal conditions, equation (10). The optimality condition defined in equation (21) gives (36)a=vσV2rfr+vγV2 After substituting equation (36) into equation (8), integration of this equation leads to (37)σ=-r6V4rf (2vσr+3vγrf )+Cσr
(38)γ=-rV4 (vσ2rfr+vγ )+Cγ where Cσ and Cγ are constants of integration. Using the boundary conditions, equations (9) and (10), constants in equations (37) and (38) are determined as (39)Cσ=rf 26V4 (2vσ+3vγ )+σfrf
(40)Cγ=rf2V4 (vσ+2vγ )+γf
(41)vσ=-2rf 2 [σf-6V4σ0-6V4 (γf-γ0 ) ] (rf-r0 )3 -6V4rf [2σ0+ (γf-γ0 ) ] (rf-r0 )2
(42)vγ=2rf 2 [σf-6V4σ0-6V4 (γf-γ0 ) ] (rf-r0 )3 -rf [σf-18σ0V4-12V4 (γf-γ0 ) ] (rf-r0 )2 -2V4 [3σ0+2 (γf-γ0 ) ]rf-r0 The conditions that the missile intercepts the target in finite time tf24 are (43)limt→tf<∞r=0
(44)limr→0σ=0 Note that if rf = 0 and σf = 0, then λf = γf. Substituting equations (41) and (42) into equation (36) and then using equations (43) and (44), the open-loop optimal solution is obtained as (45)a=-V2 [6r (2σ0+γf-γ0 ) -2r0 (3σ0+2γf-2γ0 ) ]r0 2 If the initial states in equation (45) are taken as current states, the closed-loop optimal solution can be obtained as (46)a=-V2 [6σ+2 (γf-γ ) ]r The derived optimal guidance law with impact angle constraint, equation (45), is equal to the law derived in Ryoo et al.7 due to the relationship, σ = γ – λ.

sec.title: Optimal impact angle control guidance law with the seeker’s FOV limits
In case of constrained flight for r2 ≤ r ≤ r1
sec.p:
The seeker look angle inequality constraint through equation (11) is rewritten as (47)s=σ-σmax≤0 Here, differentiating equation (47) with respect to r yields (48)dsdr=-σr-aV2 Since the control variable (a) appears explicitly in equation (48), the seeker look angle inequality constraint, equation (47), is a first-order state variable inequality constraint. Then, y and z can be defined as (49)y=σ-σmax=0
(50)z=γ Equation (49) means that the seeker has the maximum look angle during the mid-guidance phase, so the optimal acceleration command to maintain the maximum look angle is needed. The Hamiltonian (F) for the constrained phase defined in ‘Necessary conditions on a constrained arc’ section is given by (51)F=12a2-aV2μ Using equations (24), (25) and (51), the differential equations of the state variable (z) and the co-state variable (μ) are given by (52)dzdr=-aV2
(53)dμdr=0 The following optimal solution to keep the look angle constant on the constraint boundary during the constrained flight is derived from equations (19) and (48) (54)aMID=-V2σr where the subscript MID represents the mid-guidance phase (r2 ≤ r ≤ r1). Therefore, by substituting the optimal solution, equation (54), into equation (8) and then integrating this equation, the trajectory solution of σ in equation (55) is obtained by the tangency condition, equation (49). (55)σMID (r )=σmax From equation (55), we can verify that the derived optimal solution, equation (54), makes the seeker look angle constant.

sec.title: In case of unconstrained flight for r1 ≤ r ≤ r0 and rf ≤ r ≤ r2.
sec.p:
For unconstrained flight, the Hamiltonian H is the same as equation (31). Thus, the co-state variable equations are also the same as equations (34) and (35), but the terminal conditions are different between the intervals. At the juncture between the constrained and unconstrained flight, equations (27) and (28) must be satisfied where (56)M= [10 ],N= [01 ]
(57)∂z∂r=0,∂y∂r=0 Hence, equations (27) and (28) give (58)μ=λγatr=r1andr=r2
(59)12a2-aV2μ=12a2-λσ (aV2+σr )-λγaV2 atr=r1andr=r2 By equation (58), the solution of equation (53) is λγ. This implies that the co-state variable associated with the flight path angle (γ) is the same for all of the guidance phases. Additionally, the following guidance command at the juncture is obtained by equation (59): (60)a (r1 )=-V2 σr1 |σ=σmax
(61)a (r2 )=-V2 σr2 |σ=σmax During r1 ≤ r ≤ r0, the missile is guided to have the maximum allowable look angle. For the optimal solution of the first guidance phase, the maximum look angle (σmax) at r1 is considered as the terminal condition. Therefore, for r1 ≤ r ≤ r0, the solution of equation (32) is obtained as (62)λσ=vσINIr1r where the notation INI denotes the initial guidance phase, and vσINI is the constant to be determined. Using equations (21), (58) and (62), the optimal acceleration command is obtained as (63)a=vσINIV2r1r+1V2μ After substituting equation (63) into equation (8), integrating this equation yields (64)σ=-r6V4 (2vσINIr1r+3μ )+CσINIr
(65)γ=-r2V4 (vσINIr1r+2μ )+CγINI From equations (9) and (49) as boundary conditions, the following constants are derived as (66)CσINI=r1 26V4 (2vσINI+3μ )+σmaxr1
(67)CγINI=r02V4r1 (vσINIr0+2μ )+γ0
(68)vσINI=-3r1 [2V4 (σmaxr1-σ0r0 )+μ (r1 2-r0 2 ) ]2 (r1 3-r0 3 ) By substituting equation (68) into equation (63), the open-loop optimal solution is given by (69)a=-3V2r (σmaxr1-σ0r0 )r1 3-r0 3 +μV2 [1-3r (r1+r0 )2 (r1 2+r1r0+r0 2 ) ] If the co-state variable (μ) becomes zero in equation (69), which means that equation (58) is not considered, and initial states are taken as current states, the following modified solution can be utilized as the optimal guidance law to satisfy the desired look angle (σd) at the predetermined missile-target distance (rd) (70)a=-3V2r (σdrd-σr )rd 3-r3 Since the optimal acceleration command must meet the condition in equation (60) at the entry point (r1), μ can be expressed as (71)μINI=-2V2 [σmax (r0 3+2r1 3 )-3σ0r0r1 2 ]r1 (r1-r0 )2 (r1+2r0 ) However, μINI is not uniquely defined at this point because r1 is not determined. The determination of r1 and r2, which are switching distances of the guidance phase, will be described later. Therefore, by substituting equation (71) into equation (69), the open-loop optimal solution is expressed as (72)aINI=V2 [3r (σmaxr0 2-2σ0r0r1+σmaxr1 2 ) -2 (σmaxr0 3-3σ0r0r1 2+2σmaxr1 3 ) ]r1 (r1+2r0 ) (r1-r0 )2 By taking initial states as current states, the closed-loop optimal solution for the initial guidance phase (r1 ≤ r ≤ r0) is given by (73)aINI=-V2 [σmax (4r1 2+r2 )+r1r (σmax-6σ ) ]r1 (r1+2r ) (r1-r )

The closed-loop optimal solution for the final guidance phase (rf ≤ r ≤ r2) is the same as equation (46) because the terminal conditions to intercept the target with the desired impact angle and the initial conditions as the current states are the same in both cases. Hence, the closed-loop optimal solution for the final guidance phase is given by (74)aFIN=-V2 [6σ+2 (γf-γ ) ]r where the subscript FIN denotes the final guidance phase.

sec.title: Determination of r1 and r2
sec.p:
To implement the optimal guidance law derived above, we need to determine the distances, r1 and r2, at which the guidance law is switched. In the section ‘Optimal control problem with a state variable inequality constraint’, the two unconstrained trajectories are coupled by z and μ. By substituting equation (54) into equation (52), the solution of equation (52) for the constrained flight (r2 ≤ r ≤ r1) can be obtained as (75)z=γ=σlnr+CγMID where σ is constant due to the solution in equation (55). The constant of integration (CγMID) is uniquely determined by the initial or terminal conditions for the constrained flight, so the flight path angle (γ) must satisfy the following conditions (76)γ (r1 - )=γ (r1 + )
(77)γ (r2 - )=γ (r2 + ) where the superscripts − and + indicate just before and after the juncture. In addition, from equation (28), the optimal acceleration commands must also satisfy the following conditions (78)a (r1 - )=a (r1 + )
(79)a (r2 - )=a (r2 + ) From equations (76) and (77), the constant (CγMID) in equation (75) can be expressed at distances r1 and r2, respectively (80) CγMID |r=r1=2r1 (γ0r1+2γ0r0-3σ0r0 ) +σmax (5r1 2-r0 2-2r1 2lnr1 +2r0r1-4r0r1lnr1 )2r1 (r1+2r0 )
(81) CγMID |r=r2=γf+σmax (52-lnr2 ) Also, using equations (58), (78) and (79), the relationship equation between r1 and r2 is derived as (82)r2 (r1 )=2σmaxr1 (r1+2r0 ) (r1-r0 )2σmax (r0 3+2r1 3 )-3σ0r0r1 2 Therefore, by equations (80) to (82), the values of r1 and r2 can be uniquely determined because there are three unknowns (r1, r2, and CγMID) in three equations. However, r1 and r2 cannot be expressed explicitly in terms of the state variables due to the complicated equations (80) to (82). Substituting equation (82) into equation (81) yields (83) CγMID |r=r2=γf +σmax [52-ln (2σmaxr1 (r1+2r0 ) (r1-r0 )2σmax (r0 3+2r1 3 )-3σ0r0r1 2 ) ] Since equation (83) is equal to equation (80), the following nonlinear function of r1 is derived (84)E (r1 )= CγMID |r=r2- CγMID |r=r1 From equation (84), r1 is numerically calculated by the Newton–Raphson method,26 and then r2 is easily determined by substituting the calculated r1 into equation (82).

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: In this section, the performance of the proposed optimal guidance law is investigated via nonlinear simulations. First, nonlinear simulations are performed when various look angle inequality constraints are given and an impact angle constraint is fixed. Second, nonlinear simulations are performed when various impact angle constraints are given and a look angle inequality constraint is fixed. Finally, the proposed guidance law is compared with other guidance laws considering the seeker’s FOV limits. In all nonlinear simulations, true states of the missile and true missile-target relative distance measurements, which do not include any error sources, were used.

If equation (54) is used as the guidance command for nonlinear simulations in order to maintain the maximum look angle of the seeker, the magnitude of the look angle varies due to the nonlinearity of equation (3). To deal with this nonlinearity, we use the following modified guidance law to keep the look angle on the constraint boundary, which is easily derived by using equations (3) and (19) (85)aMID=-V2sinσr Equation (85) is a deviated pure pursuit guidance law,16 and it is the same as the constant look angle guidance law derived in Sang and Tahk.19 Therefore, as the missile approaches the target, the guidance commands for the nonlinear simulations are calculated as follows (86)a= {-V2 [σmax (4r1 2+r2 )+r1r (σmax-6σ ) ]r1 (r1+2r ) (r1-r )forr1≤r≤r0-V2sinσrforr2≤r≤r1-V2 [6σ+2 (γf-γ ) ]rforrf≤r≤r2

sec.title: Nonlinear simulation for various look angle inequality constraints
sec.p:
Nonlinear simulations are performed for various look angle inequality constraints, and the desired impact angle is fixed as −60° with the initial conditions shown in Table 1. When the maximum look angle is 90°, this means that the seeker has no FOV limit. Table 1.
Initial conditions for nonlinear simulations.
Parameters Values
Missile position (x0, z0) (0, 0) m
Target position (xt, zt) (4000, 0) m
Missile velocity (V) 200 m/s
Missile seeker’s FOV ±10–25° or ±90°
Launch angle (γ0) 5°
Impact angle (γf) −90°–90°

The missile trajectories for various σmax are shown in Figure 4. As shown in Figure 5, the guidance command is almost linear to time for σmax = 90°, but is not linear for the other cases because the proposed guidance law is changed at the switching distances (r1, r2) determined by equations (82) and (84). The smaller σmax is given, the longer the mid-guidance phase to maintain the maximum look angle takes. As a result, the acceleration command increases as the missile approaches near the target. From Figure 6, the look angle approaches the constraint boundary during the initial guidance phase except for σmax = 90°, and then the seeker has the constant look angle during the mid-guidance phase. The mid-guidance phase is changed to the final guidance phase if the relative distance (r) satisfies r2, and then the look angle becomes zero to intercept the target. When σmax = 90°, the maximum look angle is about 30°. This implies that the seeker must have a FOV wider than about ± 30° to implement the optimal impact angle control guidance law without the seeker’s FOV limits, which is explained in equation (46). Also, it is shown that impact angle control guidance is possible using the proposed law, although the seeker has an FOV narrower than about ±30°. The smaller σmax is given, the larger the missile maneuver appears during the final guidance phase in Figure 7. From these results, the maximum look angle inequality constraint (σmax) should be determined taking into account the missile acceleration capability because the command saturation caused by large commands during the final guidance phase can induce large miss distances and impact angle errors. Figure 4.
Missile trajectories for various look angle inequality constraints and γf = −60°.
Figure 5.
Guidance commands for various look angle inequality constraints and γf = −60°.
Figure 6.
Seeker look angles for various look angle inequality constraints and γf = −60°.
Figure 7.
Flight path angles for various look angle inequality constraints and γf = −60°.

sec.title: Nonlinear simulation for various impact angles
sec.p:
Now, nonlinear simulations are performed for various impact angles and the seeker’s FOV defined as ±15° with the same initial conditions shown in Table 1. The missile trajectories and guidance commands are shown in Figures 8 and 9, respectively. As seen in Figure 9, the guidance commands rapidly increase for γf = ± 90° during the final guidance phase and are almost linear to time for γf = 0° because the seeker look angle is not limited in the case of γf = 0°. The seeker look angles and the flight path angles are shown in Figures 10 and 11. The proposed guidance law can intercept the target without missing the target within the seeker’s FOV for all impact angle constraints. However, the maximum impact angle constraint should be determined also taking into account the missile acceleration capability and the seeker’ FOV because large commands are generated during the final guidance phase when a high impact angle constraint is imposed. Figure 8.
Missile trajectories for various impact angles and |σmax| = 15°.
Figure 9.
Guidance commands for various impact angles and |σmax| = 15°.
Figure 10.
Seeker look angles for various impact angles and |σmax| = 15°.
Figure 11.
Flight path angles for various impact angles and |σmax| = 15°.

sec.title: Comparisons with other guidance laws considering the seeker’ FOV limits
sec.p: The performance of the proposed optimal guidance law is compared with the circular-navigation-guidance (CNG) described in Manchester and Savkin12 and the guidance law switching logic considering the seeker’s FOV limits described in Sang and Tahk.19 CNG and guidance law switching logics are summarized as follows.

sec.title: Circular-navigation-guidance
sec.p: This guidance law is based on the geometrical principle of following a circular path to the target. When the target is stationary, it comprises two terms: one is 2Vλ·, which makes the missile follow a circular path, and the other is KP[σ + ɛ], which leads the missile to converge to the correct circular path (87)aCNG= {2Vλ·-KP [σ+ɛ ]if |ɛ |∈ [0,σmax )Vλ·-KP [σ+σmaxsign (ɛ ) ]if |ɛ |∈ [σmax,π ) where KP is the constant gain, ɛ is the approach-angle error defined as the difference between the LOS and the desired impact angle. In equation (87), CNG is implemented using the switching rule as the magnitude of the approach-angle error (|ɛ|) to avoid missing the target within the seeker’s FOV.

sec.title: Guidance law switching logic
sec.p: The concept of this switching logic is to change the original guidance law to the constant target look angle guidance law when the seeker look angle approaches the FOV limit and then to return to the original guidance law when the specific condition is satisfied. The constant target look angle guidance law is the same as equation (85). Lyapunov theory is used to define the returning point from the constant target look angle guidance law to the original guidance law. A Lyapunov function is defined as σ2/2, and then conditions for the return to the original guidance law are determined to make this function negative definite and to decrease the look angle to zero. The returning conditions can be expressed as (88)aORI<-V2rsinσmaxifσmax>0aORI>-V2rsinσminifσmin<0 where the subscript ORI denotes the original guidance command. Since any guidance law in this switching logic can be applied, equation (46) is used as the original guidance law.

For comparison with other guidance laws, the seeker’s FOV limits and the predetermined impact angles are defined in Table 2, and initial conditions are the same in Table 1. The comparison results of missile trajectories and guidance commands for |σmax| = 12° and γf = 30° and −50° are shown in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. The comparison results for |σmax| = 18° and γf = −50° and 70° are shown in Figures 14 and 15, respectively. The missile intercepts the target satisfying the terminal impact angle without lock-on failure in all cases. From Table 2, the proposed guidance law spends the least control energy among the considered laws. The control energy of the proposed guidance law and Sang and Tahk19 is similar because the derived optimal impact angle control guidance law, equation (46), is used as the original guidance law and the constant look angle guidance law is also the same. However, these results imply that using the proposed guidance law for the initial guidance phase is more efficient in terms of the control energy than using the same guidance law for the initial and final phases. Figure 12.
Missile trajectories for |σmax| = 12°.
Figure 13.
Guidance commands for |σmax| = 12°.
Figure 14.
Missile trajectories for |σmax| = 18°.
Figure 15.
Guidance commands for |σmax| = 18°.
Table 2.
Comparisons of the proposed guidance law with other guidance laws.
Parameters Proposed guidance law Sang and Tahk19 CNG (Kp = 500)
Seeker’s FOV, deg γf, deg J, m2/s3 J, m2/s3 J, m2/s3
±12 30 1335 1341 3106
±12 −50 4987 5004 5289
±18 −50 2883 2902 3859
±18 70 9331 9376 12,021

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: In this article, we have proposed an optimal impact angle control guidance law considering the seeker’s FOV limits for missiles with strapdown seekers. To handle the seeker’s FOV limits, the look angle inequality constraint is introduced during the homing phase. The proposed optimal guidance law is composed of three types of acceleration commands. The first command is to approach the maximum look angle of the seeker during the initial guidance phase. The second is to keep the look angle constant during the mid-guidance phase. The third is the optimal impact angle control guidance command during the final guidance phase. The switching distances to change the guidance laws are uniquely determined using the relationship of the acceleration command and the constant of integration of the flight path angle between the entry and exit points. The performance of the proposed guidance law was demonstrated through nonlinear simulations for various conditions. In case of a very narrow FOV of the seeker or high impact angles, the final guidance commands can increase rapidly, so the look angle and desired impact angle constraints should be defined considering the missile’s acceleration capability to reduce the miss-distances and impact angle errors, which can be caused by command saturation.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
